Package com.nymi.api Description

Nymi's Android API for interacting with Nymi Bands.

The Nymi Android API enables Android applications to interact with Nymi Bands. Nymi Bands are represented in the API as NymiDevice objects. The following Nymi Band interactions are currently supported:

  • Sending notification (i.e. motor vibe or led flash)
  • Querying the PRG stream
  • Signing a message (against a previously established signature key)

Each of the above operations are executed with a method call on a NymiDevice instance. These methods always take parameter arguments and a callback. The API takes care of locating the device, connecting to it, and executing the operation. The results of the operation will be delivered to the callback registered at operation dispatch. Each operation can timeout, which will happen if a NymiDevice is not in or leaves proximity while an operation is in progress, however this is the extent of the error-handling for which your application is responsible.

Like bluetooth devices, NymiBands are not accessible to arbitrary applications. NymiBands employ a randomized advertisement protocol, which includes frequent MAC address rotation, to keep them inaccessible to and untrackable by applications that have not been specifically authorized by their wearer. An NEA can detect the presence of bands to which it has not (yet) been authorized, but has no means of identifying such bands (e.g. it has no means to conclude whether detection events were generated by the same band).

An NEA becomes authorized to find and interact with a NymiBand through a process called provisioning, the result of which, called a provision, is data shared between the NEA and the Nymi Band. Provisions are managed by the NymiAdapter. The NymiAdapter enables an NEA to provision Nymi Band, it persists all provisions it creates, and gives the access to all provisioned bands as NymiDevice instances (via NymiAdapter.getDevices()).

Provisioning is a multi-step process involving a Nymi Band, it's wearer, the Nymi API, and an NEA. The provisioning process is as follows:

  • The user puts the band into provisioning mode
  • The Nymi Band broadcasts its willingness to provision with new applications
  • The NymiAdapter is listening for intent to provision and initiates the provisioning process. Initiating provisioning causes the provisioning band to display a fixed LED pattern.
  • An application communicates intent to provision the device, by communicating the LED hash of the target band (specified by the user).
  • The NymiAdapter completes the provisioning process, returning a NymiDevice to the application

Provisioning can fail due to environmental factors (i.e. noise on the Bluetooth spectrum); however the provisioning process is atomic: it either completes, resulting in a provision and a new NymiDevice for the application, or it fails and must be repeated anew.

Note that provisions are a long-lived resource, are persisted by both the adapter and the band itself. Each band can store only a limited number of provisions, which can be managed by the user (with the companion application). Applications should create a single provision for each device they want to be able to interact with. The NymiAdapter does not currently enforce that only one provision is created for one band, but this behaviour is likely to change in the future to prevent applications from accidentally establishing multiple provisions with the same band.
